akn:section.akn:heading: Rules and regulations defining practice of law and prescribing procedures for practice of law by law students, codes of ethics, use of limited liability companies, and disciplinary procedure

akn:content.akn:p: Text The Supreme Court may promulgate rules and regulations: Defining the practice of law. Prescribing procedures for the limited practice of law by third-year law students. Prescribing a code of ethics governing the professional conduct of attorneys including the practice of law or patent law through professional law corporations, limited liability companies, and partnerships, and a code of judicial ethics. Prescribing procedures for disciplining, suspending, and disbarring attorneys. History History. Code 1950, § 54-48; 1973, c. 484; 1974, c. 456; 1988, c. 765; 1992, c. 574. Annotations Cross references. For rules of court which relate to the practice of law, the code of professional responsibility, and the canons of judicial conduct, see Volume 11, Rules of Court , Pt. 6, §§ I, II and III. For rules which concern the organization and government of the Virginia State Bar, see Volume 11, Rules of Court, Pt. 6, § IV. Law Review. For comment, Student Practice  Limited Appearances in Court by Third Year Law Students, see 6 U. Rich. L. Rev. 152 (1971). For note on procedures for disciplining attorneys in Virginia, see 29 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 439 (1972). For note, Minimum Fee Schedules  The Battle and the War: Goldfarb at the Fourth Circuit, see 60 Va. L. Rev. 1415 (1974). For note on the free speech  fair trial controversy and Disciplinary Rule 7-107 of the ABA Code of Professional Responsibility, see 37 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 219 (1980). For article, The Duty to Settle, see 76 Va. L. Rev. 1113 (1990). For an article, Professional Responsibility, see 31 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1115 (1997). Research References. Bryson on Virginia Civil Procedure (Matthew Bender). Chapter 2 Potential Jurisdiction. § 2.03 Courts. Bryson. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 1 Courts. § 1.01 The Court System. Friend. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Attorney and Client, § 2. CASE NOTES Editors note. Most of the cases annotated below were decided under prior law. Interest of the states in regulating lawyers is especially great since lawyers are essen tial to the primary governmental function of administering justice and have historically been officers of the courts. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). The admission or exclusion of an attorney is not the exercise of a mere ministerial power. It is the exercise of judicial power and the admission of an attorney may, with propriety, be entrusted to the courts. Brown v. Supreme Court of Virginia, 359 F. Supp. 549, 1973 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13352 (E.D. Va.), aff'd, 414 U.S. 1034, 94 S. Ct. 534, 38 L. Ed. 2d 327, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1459 (1973). It is universally recognized that the highest court of the state may prescribe rules relating to admissions to the bar even in the absence of a statute. Brown v. Supreme Court of Virginia, 359 F. Supp. 549, 1973 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13352 (E.D. Va.), aff'd, 414 U.S. 1034, 94 S. Ct. 534, 38 L. Ed. 2d 327, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1459 (1973). Rules may authorize State Bar activities not enumerated.  The Supreme Court may adopt rules authorizing the State Bar to engage in activities not specifically enumerated in this article. Button v. Day, 204 Va. 547, 132 S .E.2d 292, 1963 Va. LEXIS 185 (1963). Such as continuing legal edu cation program.  Under rules adopted by the Supreme Court, the Council of the State Bar had authority to participate in a program of continuing legal education, which program tend s to advance the science of jurisprudence and to facilitate the administration of justice. Button v. Day, 204 Va. 547, 132 S.E.2d 292, 1963 Va. LEXIS 185 (1963). This section provides no standards for the Virginia Court to follow in regulating attorneys; it is apparent that insofar as the substantive content of such a code is concerned, the State has vested in the court virtually its entire legislative or regulatory power over the legal profession. Supreme Court v. Consumers Union of United States, Inc., 446 U.S. 719, 100 S. Ct. 1967, 64 L. Ed. 2d 641, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 108 (1980). Ethical code direc ts noncontrol by fee schedules.  The Virginia Supreme Court has adopted ethical codes which deal in part with fees and far from exercising State power to authorize binding price fixing has explic itly directed lawyers not to be controlled by fee schedules. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). No diminution of S tate regulatory power intended.  In holding that certain anticompetitive conduct by lawyers is within the reach of the Sherman Act, the Supreme Court of the United States intended no diminution o f the authority of the State to regulate its professions. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). Circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to revoke attorney's license.  Commonwealths statutory scheme did not grant the circuit court the power to disbar attorneys, and the circuit court lacked authority to grant a citizen the re lief he desired, the revocation of a county Commonwealth attorneys license; Virginia law did not authorize the revocation or disbarment proceedings the citizen sought to pursue in any other form, nor did it provide for individual citizens to prosecut e disbarment or disciplinary proceedings against attorneys in circuit courts. Spanos v. Taylor, 2023 Va. App. LEXIS 143 (Va. Ct. App. Mar. 7, 2023). Lawyers price-fixing activities held violative of Sherman Antitrust Act.  See Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). The Supreme Court of Virginia acted in a legislative capacity in adopting the disciplinary rules under this section. Hirschkop v. Virginia State Bar, 421 F. Supp. 1137, 1976 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13858 (E.D. Va. 1976), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 594 F.2d 356, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 16505 (4th Cir. 1979).

akn:section.akn:heading: Organization and government of Virginia State Bar

akn:content.akn:p: Text The Supreme Court may promulgate rules and regulations organizing and governing the Virginia State Bar. The Virginia State Bar shall act as an administrative agency of the Court for the purpose of investigating and reporting violations of rules and regulations adopted by the Court under this article. All advisory opinions issued by the Virginia State Bars Standing Committees on Legal Ethics, Lawyer Advertising and Solicitation, and Unauthorized Practice of Law shall be incorporated into the Code of Virginia pursuant to § 30-154. All persons engaged in the practice of law in the Commonwealth shall be active members in good standing of the Virginia State Bar. History History. Code 1950, § 54-49; 1974, c. 536; 1991, c. 564; 2002, c. 306. Annotations Editors note. Acts 2020, c. 1289, as amended by Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 552, Item 51 A, effective for the biennium ending June 30, 2022, provides: It is the intention of the General Assembly that the Virginia State Bar strictly direct its activities toward the purposes of regulating the legal profession and improving the quality of legal services available to the people of the Commonwealth, and that, insofar as reasonab ly possible, the Virginia State Bar shall refrain from commercial or other undertakings not necessarily or reasonably related to the above stated purposes. Acts 2020, c. 1289, as amended by Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 552, Item 51 C, effective for the biennium ending June 30, 2022, provides: The Virginia State Bar shall review its member fee structure and make changes necessary to ensure fees are set at amounts needed only to cover costs and to provide for an appropriate balance. The 2002 amendments. The 2002 amendment by c. 306 inserted Lawyer Advertising and Solicitation in the third sentence. Law Review. For note on procedures for disciplining attorneys in Virginia, see 29 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 439 (1972). For survey of Virginia law on business associations for the year 1974-1975, see 61 Va. L. Rev. 1650 (1975). For survey on professional responsibility in Virginia for 1989, see 23 U. Rich. L. Rev. 751 (1989). For an article, Professional Responsibility, see 31 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1115 (1997). Research References. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 1 Courts. § 1.01 The Court System. Charles E. Friend. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Attorney and Client, § 57. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases annotated below were decided under prior law. In enacting disciplinary rules, the Supreme Court of Virginia is constituted a legislature. Supreme Court v. Consumers Union of United States, Inc., 446 U.S. 719, 100 S. Ct. 1967, 64 L. Ed. 2d 641, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 108 (1980). Immuni ty from suit while acting in legislative capacity.  The Supreme Court of Virginia is exercising the States entire legislative power with respect to regulating the bar and its members are the States legislat ors for the purpose of issuing the Bar Code, thus the Supreme Court of Virginia and its members are immune from suit when acting in their legislative capacity. Supreme Court v. Consumers Union of United States, Inc., 446 U.S. 719, 100 S. Ct. 1967, 64 L. Ed. 2d 641, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 108 (1980). Interest of the states in regulating lawyers is especially great since lawyers are essen tial to the primary governmental function of administering justice and have historically been officers of the courts. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). Circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to revoke attorney's license.  Commonwealths statutory scheme did not grant the circuit court the power to disbar attorneys, and the circuit court lacked authority to grant a citizen the re lief he desired, the revocation of a county Commonwealth attorneys license; Virginia law did not authorize the revocation or disbarment proceedings the citizen sought to pursue in any other form, nor did it provide for individual citizens to prosecut e disbarment or disciplinary proceedings against attorneys in circuit courts. Spanos v. Taylor, 2023 Va. App. LEXIS 143 (Va. Ct. App. Mar. 7, 2023). State bar is state agency by law. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). Granting of the Virginia State Bars motion to dismiss an attorneys complaint under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 was proper because the bar was an agency of the S upreme Court of Virginia and it was therefore protected by U.S. Const., Amend. XI. Hunter v. Va. State Bar, 786 F. Supp. 2d 1107, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 49232 (E.D. Va. 2011). Attorneys failure to disclose in his application to qualify as an attorney for the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Virginia that he was publ icly reprimanded by the Virginia State Bar was grounds for denial, as it violated the duty of candor he owed to the bankruptcy court. His argument that the term any court in the application referred only to the Supreme Court of Virginia was a del iberate attempt to parse the language in the application to his own purposes in order to circumvent disclosure, and even if the state bar was not an administrative agency of the Supreme Court of Virginia, the term would nevertheless apply where it was pr esiding in its capacity as an adjudicative tribunal deciding ethical conduct matters. In re Fisher, No. 15-00301-KRH, 2015 Bankr. LEXIS 4025 (Bankr. E.D. Va. May 11, 2015). But not an antitrust shield.  The fact that the State Bar is a state agency for some limited purposes does not create an antitrust shield that allows it to foster anticompetitive practices for the benefit of its members. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). And joining in anticompetitive activity is not beyond Sherman Act.  The State Bar, by providing that deviation from county bar minimum fees may lead to disciplinary action, has voluntarily joined in what is essentially a private a nticompetitive activity, and in that posture cannot claim it is beyond the reach of the Sherman Act. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). La wyers price-fixing activities violative of Sherman Act.  Activities which resulted in a rigid price floor for a lawyers service in doing a title search, from which petitioners, as consumers, could not escape if they wished to borrow money to buy a home, were violative of the Sherman Antitrust Act. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). No diminution of S tate regulatory power intended.  In holding that certain anticompetitive conduct by lawyers is within the reach of the Sherman Act, the Supreme Court of the United States intended no diminution o f the authority of the State to regulate its professions. Goldfarb v. Virginia State Bar, 421 U.S. 773, 95 S. Ct. 2004, 44 L. Ed. 2d 572, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 13 (1975). Powers of bar.  Composition of the board considering disciplinary violations against the attorney did not affect the jurisdiction of the bar pursuant to § 54.1-3910 to investi gate and report attorney violations. Thus, the attorney could not complain that the bar should not have been able to bring charges of misconduct against the attorney because the attorneys former attorney was on the subcommittee that certified the cha rges, as the attorney waived any irregularity by not timely objecting. Green v. Va. State Bar, 278 Va. 162, 677 S.E.2d 227, 2009 Va. LEXIS 67 (2009). OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL Activities aimed at promoting di versity.  Efforts of the Virginia State Bar to promote diversity in the legal profession represent a legitimate state interest, and promoting diversity is reasonably relate d to regulating the legal profession and improving the quality of legal services to the public. It would therefore be constitutionally permissible for the Virginia State Bar to fund the Diversity Conference using mandatory state bar dues. The Virginia State Bar is not required to create procedures by which members may challenge the use of dues for any bar activity to which they object, so long as its activities remain germane to the practice of law. See opinion of Attorney General to Honorable Jennife r T. Wexton, Member, Senate of Virginia, No. 15-004, (10/2/15). § 54.1-3910.1. Enforcement, etc., of costs. Text Orders of the Disciplinary Board regarding unpaid costs assessed by the Clerk of the Disciplinary System pursuant to Part Six, Section IV, Paragraph 13 of the Rules of the Supreme Court may be recorded, enforced, and satisfied as orders or decrees of a circuit court upon certification of such order by the Disciplinary Board. History History. 2001, c. 225.

akn:section.akn:heading: Transmission of certain information to the House Committee for Courts of Justice and the Senate Committee on the Judiciary

akn:content.akn:p: Text The Virginia State Bar is authorized to transmit to the House Committee for Courts of Justice and the Senate Committee on the Judiciary, upon request of the chairman of either Committee, any evidence that it has in its possession with reference to any pending disciplinary proceeding involving a licensed attorney whose name has been placed before the Committee for consideration for election as a judge of a court of this Commonwealth and the record of any previous disciplinary action taken against the attorney. History History. 1985, c. 264, § 54-49.1; 1988, c. 765. Annotations Cross references. As to proceedings pending disciplinary action, see § 54.1-3936. Editors note. The Virginia Code Commission authorized the substitution of the House Committee for Courts of Justice and the Senate Committee on the Judiciary for th e House and Senate Committees for Courts of Justice. March 10, 2021.

Text The Supreme Court may promulgate rules and regulations fixing a schedule of fees to be paid by members of the Virginia State Bar for the purpose of administering this a rticle, and providing for the collection and disbursement of such fees; but the annual fees to be paid by any attorney shall not exceed $250. History History. Code 1950, § 54-50; 1956, c. 256; 1964, c. 332; 1970, c. 605; 1975, c. 218; 1982, c. 602; 1986, c. 205; 1988, c. 765; 1993, c. 38; 1995, c. 15. Annotations Editors note. Acts 2020, c. 1289, as amended by Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 552, and Acts 2022, Sp. Sess. I, c. 2Item 39 O 2, effective for the biennium ending June 30, 2023, pr ovides: Notwithstanding the provisions of § 54.1-3912, Code of Virginia, in addition to any other fee permitted by law, the Supreme Court of Virginia may adopt rules assessing members of the Virginia State Bar an annual fee of up to $30 to be depo sited in the State Bar Fund and transferred to the Attorney Wellness Fund. Research References. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 1 Courts. § 1.01 The Court System. Charles E. Friend. OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL Forfeiture of license.  Suspension of a law license for failure to pay Virginia State Bar annual fees within 60 days of notice of delinquency under the Rules of the Supreme Court of Virg inia does not conflict with the penalty of license forfeiture imposed by the General Assembly in § 54.1-3914 for nonpayment of fees for two successive years. See opinion of Attorney General to Honorable Debra H. Rodman, Member, Virginia House of Dele gates, 19-030, (11/8/19).

Text The State Bar Fund is continued as a special fund in the state treasury. All fees collected from the members of the Virginia State Bar as provided in § 54.1-3912 sha ll be paid into the state treasury immediately upon collection and credited to the State Bar Fund. All moneys paid into the Fund are hereby appropriated to the Virginia State Bar for the purpose of administering the provisions of this article. All disbur sements from the Fund shall be made by the State Treasurer upon warrants of the Comptroller issued upon vouchers signed by an authorized officer of the Virginia State Bar in accordance with rules and regulations promulgated by the Supreme Court. History History. Code 1950, § 54-52; 1964, c. 531; 1974, c. 608; 1979, c. 440; 1988, c. 765. Annotations Law Review. For note on procedures for disciplining attorneys in Virginia, see 29 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 439 (1972). CASE NOTES Fund may be used for counsel fees in prosecuting unauthorized practice of law.  State Bar funds may legitimately be used to pay fees to special counsel for prosecuting suits to enjoin the unauthorized practice of the law, provided the attorne ys are specially employed for that purpose upon request of the Attorney General. Button v. Day, 204 Va. 547, 132 S.E.2d 292, 1963 Va. LEXIS 185 (1963) (decided under prior law). Or to publish Virginia Bar News.  The publication by the State Bar of the newsletter called the Virginia Bar News is a permitted activity. It is not a law magazine whose publication is prohibited by the State Bar Act. Button v. Day, 204 Va. 547, 132 S.E.2d 292, 1963 Va. LEXIS 185 (1963) (decided under prior law). § 54.1-3913.1. Clients Protection Fund. Text The Clients Protection Fund is continued as a special fund of the Virginia State Bar. The Fund shall consist of moneys transferred to it from the State Bar Fund and the Virginia State Bars Administration and Finance Account. Disbursements to the Clients Protection Fund from the State Bar Fund shall be made only upon approval of the disbursements through the annual budgetary process of the Virginia State Bar . Notwithstanding the provisions of § 54.1-3912, the Supreme Court may adopt rules assessing members of the Virginia State Bar an annual fee of up to $25 to be deposited in the State Bar Fund and transferred to the Clients Protection Fund. History History. 1996, c. 346; 2007, c. 807. Annotations Editors note. Acts 2007, c. 807, cl. 2, as amended by Acts 2014, c. 512, cl. 1 and Acts 2018, c. 478, cl. 1, provides: That the provisions of this act shall expire on Ju ly 1, 2023. The 2007 amendments. The 2007 amendment by c. 807, as amended by Acts 2014, c. 8512, cl. 1, expires July 1, 2020, and added the last sentence. Editor's note. Acts 2022, c. 632, cl. 1 provides: That the second enactment of Chapter 807 of the Acts of Assembly of 2007, as amended by Chapter 512 of the Acts of Assembl y of 2014 and Chapter 478 of the Acts of Assembly of 2018, is repealed. Research References. Attorneys Handbook of Accounting, Auditing, and Financial Reporting (Matthew Bender). Martin. How to Manage Your Law Office (Matthew Bender). Altman and Weil. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Attorney and Client, § 29.

akn:section.akn:heading: Forfeiture of license for failing to pay fees; restoration of license

akn:content.akn:p: Text Any attorney licensed to practice in this Commonwealth who fails for two successive years to pay the annual fees provided for by § 54.1-3912, shall thereby forfeit h is license to practice law in this Commonwealth. On or before July 31 of each year, the Executive Director of the Virginia State Bar shall notify every attorney whose fees for the two preceding years have not been pai d. The notice shall be deemed to have been given if deposited by registered or certified mail addressed to such attorney at his address as shown on the Executive Directors official records. If payment is not received by the Executive Director within six months from the date of such notice, he shall remove the name of the attorney from his list of persons qualified to practice law in Virginia, and shall notify the clerk of the Supreme Court of Virginia that the name of the attorney has been removed. The name of any attorney so removed shall be restored only upon application of such person to the Executive Director accompanied by a sum equal to the aggregate of all fees which are due, plus a penalty of $100. Upon receipt of the fees and penalty, the Executive Director shall restore the name of such person to his list of persons qualified to practice law in Virginia and shall notify the clerk of the Supreme Court of Virginia that such name has been restored. History History. 1960, c. 459, § 54-50.1; 1984, c. 359; 1988, c. 765. Annotations OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL Forfeiture of license.  Suspension of a law license for failure to pay Virginia State Bar annual fees within 60 days of notice of delinquency under the Rules of the Supreme Court of Virg inia does not conflict with the penalty of license forfeiture imposed by the General Assembly in § 54.1-3914 for nonpayment of fees for two successive years. See opinion of Attorney General to Honorable Debra H. Rodman, Member, Virginia House of Dele gates, 19-030, (11/8/19).

akn:section.akn:heading: Restrictions as to rules and regulations

akn:content.akn:p: Text Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this article, the Supreme Court shall not promulgate rules or regulations prescribing a code of ethics governing the profess ional conduct of attorneys which are inconsistent with any statute; nor shall it promulgate any rule or regulation or method of procedure which eliminates the jurisdiction of the courts to deal with the discipline of attorneys. In no case shall an attorn ey who demands to be tried by a court of competent jurisdiction for the violation of any rule or regulation adopted under this article be tried in any other manner. History History. Code 1950, § 54-51; 1974, c. 536; 1988, c. 765. Annotations Research References. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 1 Courts. § 1.01 The Court System. Charles E. Friend. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Attorney and Client, § 55, 57. CASE NOTES This section forbids inconsistency with former § 18.1-107 (now § 18.2-108). In re R yder, 263 F. Supp. 360, 1967 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11009 (E.D. Va.), aff'd, 381 F.2d 713, 1967 U.S. App. LEXIS 5558 (4th Cir. 1967) (decided under prior law). The role of the State Bar is limited to the investigation of violations and the filing of appropriate complaints in the proper courts. Supreme Court v. Consumers Union of United States, Inc., 446 U.S. 719, 100 S. Ct. 1967, 64 L. Ed. 2d 641, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 108 (1980) (decided under prior law). Time limitation on demanding trial before a three-judge court does not conflict with § 54.1-3915.  Time limitation in former Va. Sup. Ct. R. pt. 6, § IV, R. 13(C)(6) for filing a demand for a trial before a three-judge court does not eliminate the jurisdicti on of the courts to deal with attorney discipline and does not deny an attorney a right to a trial of disciplinary charges before a three-judge court in violation of § 54.1-3915; the rule merely fills in a void in the statute regarding when and how a demand for a trial before a three-judge court must be made. Fails v. Va. State Bar, 265 Va. 3, 574 S.E.2d 530, 2003 Va. LEXIS 11 (2003). Rule deeming an answer to a certification of charges to be consent to the jurisidiction of the Virginia State Disciplinary Board does not conflict with § 54.1-3915.  Provision of former Va. Sup. Ct. R. pt. 6, § IV, R. 13(C)(6) that an attorneys filing of an answer to a certification of charges of misconduct shall be con clusively deemed to be a consent to the jurisdiction of the Virginia State Bar Disciplinary Board does not conflict with the mandate of § 54.1-3915 that an attorney who demands to be tried for disciplinary charges before a court of competent jurisdict ion is to be tried before no other forum; nothing in § 54.1-3915 suggests that the right to be tried by a three-judge court cannot be waived, and an attorney who fails to file a timely demand for a trial before a three-judge court effectively waives t he right to demand such a forum for the charges against the attorney. Fails v. Va. State Bar, 265 Va. 3, 574 S.E.2d 530, 2003 Va. LEXIS 11 (2003). Term ination of authority of State Bar Disciplinary Board.  When an attorney timely demanded his alleged violations be tried before a three-judge court, the Virginia State Bar Disciplinary Boards authority terminated a nd it had no authority to enter its order suspending the attorneys license. Cilman v. Va. State Bar, 266 Va. 66, 580 S.E.2d 830, 2003 Va. LEXIS 63 (2003). Attorneys remanded appeal to a Disciplinary Board for reconsideration did not trigger any new right for him to then request a three-judge court under § 54. 1-3915 and former Va. Sup. Ct. R. pt. 6, § IV, R. 13(I)(1)(a)(1)(a). Green v. Va. State Bar ex rel. Seventh Dist. Comm., 274 Va. 775, 652 S.E.2d 118, 2007 Va. LEXIS 134 (2007). Circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to revoke attorney's license.  Commonwealths statutory scheme did not grant the circuit court the power to disbar attorneys, and the circuit court lacked authority to grant a citizen the re lief he desired, the revocation of a county Commonwealth attorneys license; the circuit court had only such subject-matter jurisdiction as was conferred by the Constitution or by statute, but the statute did not confer jurisdiction, and the circuit c ourt was without authority to redress the citizens claims. Spanos v. Taylor, 2023 Va. App. LEXIS 143 (Va. Ct. App. Mar. 7, 2023). Circuit court lacked jurisdiction to revoke an attorneys license to practice law in Virginia as Virginias statutory scheme did not provide a mechanism all owing citizens to file such actions. The statute the client relied on, Va. Code Ann. § 54.1-3915, required that the Supreme Court of Virginias rules, regulations, and modes of procedure governing legal ethics be consistent with the governing statu tes and did not confer a personal right on an individual to file an ethics complaint in a circuit court, rather than with the Bar. Spanos v. Feinmel, 2023 Va. App. LEXIS 155 (Va. Ct. App. Mar. 7, 2023). § 54.1-3915.1. Repealed by Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 342, cl. 2, effective July 1, 2021. Annotations Editors note. Former § 54.1-3915.1, pertaining to rules regarding client accounts, derived from 1995, c. 93.

Text A. The Virgini a State Bar through its governing body is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations governing the function and operation of legal aid societies to further the objective of providing legal assistance to persons requiring such assistance but unable to pay for it. To the extent that interest is paid by a financial institution on client funds deposited by attorneys or law firms in pooled interest-bearing accounts, any interest earned on such accounts shall be paid by the financial institution periodica lly, but at least quarterly, to the Legal Services Corporation of Virginia. B. The rules a nd regulations adopted under subsection A may be enforced by the Virginia State Bar, or by the Attorney General if so authorized by the Virginia State Bar. C. It shall be a Class 1 misdemeanor for any person, firm, corporation, or other organization to render legal services as a legal aid society, or for any attorney to render legal services at the instance or request of any such person, firm, corporation, or organizatio n unless the person, firm, corporation, or organization complies with the rules and regulations adopted under subsection A. In addition to the criminal penalty, an injunction shall lie to prevent any violation of this section or rule or regulation adopte d hereunder. History History. 1956, Ex. Sess., c. 47; 1958, c. 253; 1988, c. 765; 1995, c. 93; 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 342. Annotations Cross references. As to punishment for Class 1 misdemeanors, see § 18.2-11. Editors note. Acts 2020, c. 1289, as amended by Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 552, Item 50 C, effective for the biennium ending June 30, 2022, provides: The Virginia State Bar and the Legal Services Corporation of Virginia shall annually, on or about January 1, provide a report to the Chairmen of the House Appropriations and Senate Finance Committees, and the Director, Department of Planning and Budget regarding the status of legal services assistance programs in the Commonwealth. The report shall include, but not be limited to, efforts to maintain and improve the accuracy of caseload data, case opening and case closure information, and program activity levels as it relates to clients. Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 342, cl. 3 provides: That any rule promulgated by the Supreme Court of Virginia requiring attorney participation in the Interest on Lawyers Trust Accounts (IOLTA) program clearly state that an attorney or law firm has no responsibility to remit interest earned to the IOLTA program. All interest earned on IOLTA accounts shall be remitted directly to the IOLTA program by the banks hol ding such accounts. Any attorney or law firm participating in the IOLTA program shall bear no ethical or accounting responsibility for remittance of IOLTA interest to the IOLTA program and shall not be subject to any disciplinary action for same. Acts and by Acts 2022, Sp. Revenues collected from fees paid by applicants for admission to the bar shall be deposited into the Board of Bar Examiners Fund. The source of nongeneral funds included in this item is the Board of Bar Exami ners Fund. Interest generated by the fund shall be retained by the fund. The 2021 Sp. Sess. I amendments. The 2021 amendment by Sp. Sess. I, c. 342, effective July 1, 2021, substituted interest-bearing accounts for interest bearing accounts established and maintained under circumstances which do not conflict with § 54.1-3915.1 in the second sentence of subsection A; and deleted hereof from the end of the first sentence in subsection C. akn:section.akn:heading: Availability of Virginia State Bar membership list

akn:content.akn:p: Text When requested, copies of the Virginia State Bar membership address list shall be made available to Virginia professional legal organizations which operate not for prof it and which regularly conduct continuing legal education programs in the Commonwealth. If specified by the requestor, the list shall be made available in computer sorted zip code sequence in a mailing label format suitable for bulk mailing. Lists shall be provided by the Virginia State Bar on a cost recovery basis. Each request for the mailing list shall be made in writing by requesting organizations to the Executive Director of the Virginia State Bar. Each request shall state the date the list is needed by the requestor and each request shall be postmarked no less than thirty days prior to such date. The cost of mailing or shipping shall be borne by the requestor. History History. 1981, c. 496, § 54-52.2:1; 1988, c. 765. Article 3. Board of Bar Examiners. -360§ 54.1-3919. Powers, rules and regulations. -360§ 54.1-3923. Compensation of members, secretary, treasurer and character and fitness committee; expenses of examinations. -360§ 54.1-3924. Fees paid by applicants.

Text The Board of Bar Examiners shall be responsible for the examination of applicants and otherwise ascertaining the qualifications of applicants for admission to the bar a nd shall be composed of five attorneys who are residents of the Commonwealth. Three members of the Board shall constitute a quorum for holding examinations or the transaction of other business. The word Board when used in this chapter shall mean the Board of Bar Examiners. History History. Code 1950, §§ 54-53, 54-55; 1988, c. 765; 1998, c. 796. Annotations The 1998 amendment, in the first sentence, inserted and otherwise ascertaining the qualifications of applicants.

Text The members of the Board shall be appointed by the Supreme Court for five-year terms. Vacancies shall be filled by the Court for the full term of five years. History History. Code 1950, § 54-54; 1988, c. 765. Annotations CASE NOTES Power of Supreme Court to review Boards decisions.  The Supreme Court has no explicit statutory authority to review the Boards decisions or to reverse its evaluation of a particular candidate. Nonetheless, it i s well settled that that Court retains such inherent power. Woodard v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 454 F. Supp. 4, 1978 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17428 (E.D. Va. 1978), aff'd, 598 F.2d 1345, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 14439 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

akn:section.akn:heading: Board to elect one of its members president; appointment of secretary and treasurer

akn:content.akn:p: Text The Board shall elect one of its members to serve as its president, and may appoint a qualified member of the Virginia State Bar to act as secretary and treasurer of th e Board. History History. Code 1950, § 54-56; 1972, c. 444; 1988, c. 765.

Text The Board shall do, or cause to be done, all things it considers necessary, convenient or expedient in connection with the preparation, conduct and grading of examinati ons, in determining the qualifications of applicants, in determining requirements for taking and passing examinations, and in granting such certificates to practice law as may be authorized by the Supreme Court. The Board may promulgate rules and regulat ions to aid in the exercise of its authority and in the discharge of its duties. History History. 1976, c. 377, § 54-57.1; 1988, c. 765; 1998, c. 796. Annotations The 1998 amendment, in the first sentence, deleted and following applicants, and inserted the language beginning and in granting such certificates. Law Review. For comment, The Investigation of Good Moral Character for Admission to the Virginia Bar  Time for a Change, see 19 U. Rich. L. Rev. 601 (1985). CASE NOTES Editors note. The cases annotated below were decided under prior law. Power of Supreme Court to review Boards decisions.  The Supreme Court has no explicit statutory authority to review the Boards decisions or to reverse its evaluation of a particular candidate. Nonetheless, it i s well settled that that Court retains such inherent power. Woodard v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 454 F. Supp. 4, 1978 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17428 (E.D. Va. 1978), aff'd, 598 F.2d 1345, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 14439 (4th Cir. 1979). The Supreme Court of Virginia has no explicit statutory authority to review the Boards decisions or to question judicially its evaluation of a particular cand idate, but the Supreme Court retains such inherent power. It is universally recognized that the highest court of the State may prescribe rules relating to admissions to the bar even in the absence of a statute. Rogers v. Supreme Court, 590 F. Supp. 102, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16096 (E.D. Va. 1984). Right of appeal from decision of Board not constitutionally required.  The right of an appeal from the decision of a trial court is not a constitutionally guaranteed right. If no constitutional deprivation be made out by a States refusal to allow appeal from a decision taking life, liberty, or property from a criminal defendant, assuredly the State is not constitutionally required to provide an appeal from a decision of its administrative arm, the Board of Bar Examiners. Rogers v. Supreme Court, 590 F. Supp. 102, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16096 (E.D. Va. 1984). Board performs judicial function on behalf of Supreme Court.  In judging the intellectual fitness of an applicant to practice law, the Board of Bar Examiners performs a judicial function on behalf of the Supreme Court of Vir ginia. Woodard v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 454 F. Supp. 4, 1978 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17428 (E.D. Va. 1978), aff'd, 598 F.2d 1345, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 14439 (4th Cir. 1979). No federal district court jurisdiction over applicants individual claims.  A federal district court does not have jurisdiction to consider an unsuccessful applicants challenge to the procedures and practices of the Board, in referenc e to that applicants particular bar examination. Woodard v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 454 F. Supp. 4, 1978 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17428 (E.D. Va. 1978), aff'd, 598 F.2d 1345, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 14439 (4th Cir. 1979). EEOC test guidelines inapplicable.  The test validation guidelines promulgated by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 do not govern profession al licensing examinations. Woodard v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 420 F. Supp. 211, 1976 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13319 (E.D. Va. 1976), aff'd, 598 F.2d 1345, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 14439 (4th Cir. 1979). Disc rimination claims improperly filed in federal court.  Since Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, by its own terms, does not apply to the bar examination, and since the Board of Bar Examiners is neither an e mployer, an employment agency, nor a labor organization within the meaning of the act, the federal district court properly dismissed discrimination claims filed by an applicant to the Virginia Bar who had failed the bar examination an d was denied admission therefore. The applicant must present his grievance to the Supreme Court of Virginia and, if it is decided adversely to him, may then petition the Supreme Court of the United States for a writ of certiorari. Woodard v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 454 F. Supp. 4, 1978 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17428 (E.D. Va. 1978), aff'd, 598 F.2d 1345, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 14439 (4th Cir. 1979).

akn:section.akn:heading: Compensation of members, secretary, treasurer and character and fitness committee; expenses of examinations

akn:content.akn:p: Text The members of the Board and members of any character and fitness committee shall each receive such compensation as established by the Rules of the Supreme Court for th e time spent in the discharge of their duties as members, and shall be entitled to reimbursement for such of their actual expenses as are necessary and ordinarily incident to travel as members of the Board or such character and fitness committee to be co mputed in accordance with §§ 2.2-2814 through 2.2-2826. The compensation of the secretary and treasurer shall be fixed by the Board. The compensation for services and expenses shall not exceed the amount received as fees from applicants, which sha ll be fixed by the rules and regulations adopted by the Board. History History. Code 1950, § 54-58; 1954, c. 709; 1956, c. 252; 1960, c. 90; 1 966, c. 25; 1970, c. 255; 1987, c. 339; 1988, c. 765; 1992, c. 734; 1993, c. 262. Annotations Editors note. Acts 1992, c. 734, which amended this section, in cl. 2 provides that the provisions of the act shall govern applications for examinations given after July 31, 19 93. The 1992 amendment, in the first sentence, inserted and members of any character and fitness committee and or such character and fitness committee. As to the applicability of this amendment, see the Editors note.

Text In order to defray the compensation, mileage and expenses above provided for, the Board shall fix by general rule or special order the fees to be paid by each applicant . History History. Code 1950, § 54-59; 1988, c. 765. Annotations Editors note. Acts 2022, Sp. Sess. I, c. 2, Item 53 B, effective for the biennium ending June 20, 2023, provides: The Virginia State Bar and the Legal Services Corporation of Virginia shall annually, on or about January 1, provide a report to the Chairs of the House Appropriations and Senate Finance and Appropriations Committees, and the Director, Department of Planning and Budget regarding the status of legal services ass istance programs in the Commonwealth. The report shall include, but not be limited to, efforts to maintain and improve the accuracy of caseload data, case opening and case closure information, and program activity levels as it relates to clients. Article 4. Text A person desiring to take an examination under this article shall file with the Board his application therefor in such form as the Board may require not later than May 10 for the next following July examination and December 15 for the next following February examination. An application shall be deemed to be timely filed if (i) it is transmitted expense prepaid to the Office of the Secretary of the Board by priority, ex press, registered, or certified mail via the United States Postal Service, or by a third party commercial carrier for next-day delivery, and (ii) the official receipt therefor issued by the United States Postal Service or by such third party commercial c arrier, which shall be exhibited on demand of the Secretary, shows such transmission or mailing to the Secretarys office on or before the prescribed deadline. History History. Code 1950, § 54-60; 1952, c. 553; 1960, c. 379; 1966, c. 157; 1968, c. 74; 1972, cc. 535, 824; 1974, c. 686; 1980, c. 533; 1987, c. 265; 1987, Sp. Sess., c. 2; 1988, c. 765; 1992, c. 734; 1998, c. 71; 2011, c. 709. Annotations Editors note. Acts 1992, c. 734, which amended this section, in cl. 2 provides that the provisions of the act shall govern applications for examinations given after July 31, 19 93. Acts 2001, c. 230, cl. 1 provides: An applicant who (i) has successfully completed all requirements for a degree from the Potomac School of Law in the Distric t of Columbia, (ii) was enrolled and attended classes at the Potomac School of Law during or prior to the 1977 fall term, (iii) was a resident of Virginia at the time of application for admission to the Potomac School of Law, (iv) has passed the bar exam ination in another state or territory of the United States or the District of Columbia, which examination included the national multistate examination, and (v) has been admitted to practice before the court of last resort in any other state or territory of the United States or the District of Columbia is eligible to sit for the Virginia bar examination. The 1992 amendment rewrote this section. As to the applicability of this amendment, see the Editors note. The 1998 amendment, in the first sentence, substituted May 10 for the next following July examination and December 15 for the next following February examination for the fifteenth day of the second month preceding the month in which the examination will be given, and added the second sentence. The 2011 amendments. The 2011 amendment by c. 709 added the clause (i) designation, and therein substituted transmitted expense prepaid for mailed postage prepaid, ins erted priority, express and added via the Unites States Postal Service, or by a third party commercial carrier for next-day delivery; and added the clause (ii) designation, and therein inserted issued by the United States Postal Servi ce or by such third party commercial carrier, of the Secretary, and such transmission or. Law Review. For survey of Virginia law on practice and pleading in the year 1971-1972, see 58 Va. L. Rev. 1309 (1972). For survey of Virginia law on constitutional law for the year 1972-1973, see 59 Va. L. Rev. 1445 (1973). For comment, The Investigation of Good Moral Character for Admission to the Virginia Bar  Time for a Change, see 19 U. Rich. L. Rev. 601 (1985). CASE NOTES Editors note. The cases annotated below were decided under prior law. Virginia has created two classes of attorneys. The first encompasses those attorneys lic ensed by examination, and the second includes those licensed without examination. In re Brown, 213 Va. 282, 191 S.E.2d 812, 1972 Va. LEXIS 348 (1972). Those licensed by examination need not show intent to practice full time as member of Virginia Bar.  As to those attorneys licensed by examination, there is no requirement of a preadmission showing of intent to practice full time as a member of the Virginia Bar. In re Brown, 213 Va. 282, 191 S.E.2d 812, 1972 Va. LEXIS 348 (1972). Th ose licensed without examination must make such showing.  As to those attorneys licensed without examination, the requirement of a preadmission showing of intent to practice full time as a member of the Virginia Bar is i mposed. In re Brown, 213 Va. 282, 191 S.E.2d 812, 1972 Va. LEXIS 348 (1972). As to both classes, residency rules apply. In re Titus, 213 Va. 289, 191 S.E.2d 798, 1972 Va. LEXIS 349 (1972). Provisions of this section do not apply to foreign attorneys seeking admission by reciprocity. Brown v. Supreme Court of Virginia, 359 F. Supp. 549, 1973 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13352 (E.D. Va.), aff'd, 414 U.S. 1034, 94 S. Ct. 534, 38 L. Ed. 2d 327, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1459 (1973). Cohabi tation improper ground for denial of certificate.  Although a state may require high standards of qualifications, such as good moral character or proficiency in its law, before it admits an applicant to the bar, s uch qualifications, to pass constitutional muster, must have a rational connection with the applicants fitness or capacity to practice law. Thus, an applicant for the right to take the Virginia Bar Examination could not be denied a certificate of hon est demeanor or good moral character on the sole ground that she and a male to whom she was not married jointly owned and resided in the same dwelling, as this conduct bears no rational connection to her fitness to practice law. Cord v. Gibb, 219 Va. 101 9, 254 S.E.2d 71, 1979 Va. LEXIS 205 (1979). § 54.1-3925.1. Proof of character and fitness required of applicant; character and fitness committee; fees. Text A. Before issu ing to any applicant a license or certificate to practice law in Virginia, the Board shall have found from satisfactory evidence produced by the applicant in such form as the Board may require that the applicant is a person of honest demeanor and good mo ral character, is over the age of eighteen and possesses the requisite fitness to perform the obligations and responsibilities of a practicing attorney at law. B. In making s uch determinations, the Board shall conduct such further inquiries, interviews and hearings as the Board may deem necessary. At the request of the Board, the Supreme Court may appoint a separate character and fitness committee, some of the members of whi ch may be persons who are not licensed attorneys, to assist in reviewing character and fitness evidence and to make recommendations to the Board based upon standards adopted by the Board; however, no applicant shall be denied a license on character and f itness reasons except by action of a majority of the Board, after notice to the applicant and an opportunity for the applicant to be heard before the Board. C. The Board s hall from time to time set character and fitness application fees sufficient to cover the costs of the character and fitness process. History History. 1992, c. 734; 1998, c. 796. Annotations Editors note. Acts 1992, c. 734, which enacted this section, in cl. 2 provides that the provisions of the act shall govern applications for examinations given after July 31, 19 93. The 1998 amendment, in subsection A, inserted or certificate near the beginning. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Attorney and Client, § 6. CASE NOTES Licensing authorit y subject to Disabilities Act.  While the boards broad authority to set licensing qualifications is well established, such authority is subject to the requirements of the Americans with Disa bilities Act. Clark v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 880 F. Supp. 430, 1995 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2263 (E.D. Va. 1995). Mental health inquiry appropriate.  At some stage in the application proceeding, some form of mental health inquiry is appropriate. Clark v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 880 F. Supp. 430, 1995 U.S. D ist. LEXIS 2263 (E.D. Va. 1995). Question d iscriminates against disabled applicants.  Question 20(b) of the bar admission questionnaire, which asked Have you within the past five (5) years, been treated or counselled for a mental, emotional or nervous disorders? is a broadly worded mental health question which discriminates against disabled applicants by imposing additional eligibility criteria. While certain severe mental or emotional disorders may pose a direct threat to public safety, t he board has made no individualized finding that obtaining evidence of mental health counseling or treatment is effective in guarding against this threat. Accordingly, the Virginia Board of Bar Examiners is enjoined from requiring that future applicants answer the question. Clark v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Exmrs., 880 F. Supp. 430, 1995 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2263 (E.D. Va. 1995). § 54.1-3925.2. Access to criminal history records. Text The Board is authorized to obtain criminal history record information relating to an applicant from any state or federal law-enforcement agency. Any information so obt ained is for the exclusive use of the Board and the character and fitness committee and shall not be released to any other person or agency except in furtherance of the investigation of the applicant or with the authorization of the applicant or upon cou rt order. History History. 1992, c. 734. Annotations Editors note. Acts 1992, c. 734, which enacted this section, in cl. 2 provides that the provisions of the act shall govern applications for examinations given after July 31, 19 93. § 54.1-3925.3. Authority for subpoenas; qualified privilege and immunity. Text A. In the cond uct of investigations and hearings, the Board and character and fitness committee may administer oaths and affirmations and may issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses and the production of papers, books, accounts, documents, and other records or tangible evidence relevant to any such investigation or hearing. Any subpoena shall be issued in the name of the Board and be signed by a member of the Board or by its secretary. B. If any pers on fails or refuses to obey a subpoena, or to give testimony, the Board shall notify the circuit court of the ...

akn:section.akn:heading: Preliminary proof of education required of applicant

akn:content.akn:p: Text Before an applicant will be permitted to take any examination under this article, the applicant shall furnish to the Board satisfactory evidence that he has: 1. Satis factorily completed legal studies amounting to at least five semesters, or the equivalent of at least five semesters on a system other than a semester system, of full-time study at a law school approved by the American Bar Association or the Board; 2. Received a bachelors degree from an accredited baccalaureate institution of higher education and studied law for three years, consisting of not less than 18 hours per week for at l east 40 weeks per year in the office of an attorney practicing in the Commonwealth, whose full time is devoted to the practice of law; 3. Studied law for at least three years partly in a law school approved by the American Bar Association or the Board and partly, for not less than 18 hours per week for at least 40 weeks per year, in the office of an attorney practicing in the Commonwealth whose full time is devoted to the practice of law; 4. Received a bachelors degree from an accredited baccalaureate institution of higher education and studied law for three years, consisting of not less than 18 hours per week for at l east 40 weeks per year, with a retired circuit court judge who served the Commonwealth as a circuit court judge for a minimum of 10 years and who at the time of commencement of the three-year study period was retired for not more than five years; or 5. Completed all degree requirements from a law school not approved by the American Bar Association, including a foreign law school, obtained an LL.M. from a law school approved by the Am erican Bar Association, and been admitted to practice law before the court of last resort in any state or territory of the United States or the District of Columbia. The attorney in whose office or the judge with whom the applicant intends to study shall be approved by the Board, which shall prescribe reasonable conditions as to the course of study. History History. Code 1950, § 54-62; 1952, c. 553; 1960, c. 379; 1980, c. 533; 1988, c. 765; 1995, c. 336; 1998, cc. 119, 796; 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 296; 2022, c. 148. Annotations Editors note. At the direction of the Virginia Code Commission, the following changes were made to conform to Acts 2016, c. 588: in subdivisions 2 and 4, substituted an acc redited baccalaureate institution of higher education for a four-year accredited college or university; and made minor stylistic changes. The 1998 amendments. The 1998 amendment by c. 119, in subdivision 2, inserted consisting of not less than eighteen hours per week for at least forty weeks per year, in subdivi sion 3, inserted for not less than eighteen hours per week for at least forty weeks per year, substituted in the office of an attorney for in the practicing attorneys office, and inserted of an attorney practicing in this Commonwealth whose full time is devoted to the practice of law; or, added present subdivision 4, and in the last paragraph, inserted or the judge with whom. The 1998 amendment by c. 796, in the introductory paragraph, deleted In addition to the certificate required by § 54.1-3925 preceding Before, a nd substituted an applicant will be permitted to take for taking. The 2021 Sp. Sess. I amendments. The 2021 amendment by Sp. Sess. I, c. 296, effective July 1, 2021, substituted the Commonwealth for this Commonwealth in subdivisions 2 and 3; add ed subdivision 5; and made stylistic changes. The 2022 amendments. The 2022 amendment by c. 148 substituted Satisfactorily completed legal studies amounting to at least five semesters, or the equivalent of at least five semes ters on a system other than a semester system, of full-time study at for Completed all degree requirements from in subdivision 1.

Text The Board shall hold at least two examinations each year, at such times as it may prescribe by general rule or special order. If only two examinations are held in any o ne year, they shall not be less than four months apart. One examination shall be held in the City of Richmond, and one in the City of Roanoke each year, unless for good cause it is necessary to hold it elsewhere. History History.
